content:
Diagnosis:	Oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma, p16 positive

Staging:		T2N2bM0 (AJCC 8th edition)
	PET-CT 12 Apr 2024 - right tonsil primary with ipsilateral level II/III nodes
	MRI 15 Apr 2024 - confirms T2 disease confined to tonsil

Biomarkers:	P16 positive, PDL1 CPS 70%

Current Status:	Pre-treatment

I reviewed [redacted name] today following completion of staging investigations. He initially presented with a 6-week history of right-sided throat pain and enlarged neck nodes. Biopsy on 5 Apr 2024 confirmed p16 positive squamous cell carcinoma.

He is otherwise fit and well with no significant past medical history. He is an ex-smoker having quit 10 years ago with a 15 pack-year history. He drinks 14 units of alcohol per week. He works as an accountant and lives with his wife.

On examination today, there is a visible right tonsillar mass approximately 3cm in size. There are palpable right level II and III nodes, largest measuring 3cm. No other abnormalities detected.

I have discussed his case at our Head & Neck MDT on 16 Apr 2024. Given his stage, performance status, and biomarker profile, the recommendation is for radical chemoradiotherapy with weekly cisplatin. I have explained the treatment process, including the expected 6-week duration of radiotherapy with weekly chemotherapy, and potential side effects including mucositis, dysphagia, xerostomia, and skin reactions.

The plan is to proceed with dental assessment next week, followed by radiotherapy planning CT. We aim to commence treatment in 2 weeks. I will review him again before treatment starts with baseline blood tests.
